questions.question: A group of students consumed fried rice in a restaurant. Six hours later, they start vomiting. What is the etiological agent?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Bacillus cereus Explanation: Bacillus cereus causes rapid-onset vomiting (within 1–6 hours) after consuming contaminated fried rice. Clinical Features of Bacillus cereus: Clinical Features Details Food Poisoning Two distinct forms: diarrhoeal and emetic . Diarrhoeal form: Linked to contaminated meat, poultry, vegetables, and pasta; symptoms appear 8-16 hours post-ingestion. Symptoms: Abdominal pain, diarrhoea (vomiting less common, fever rare) Emetic form : Associated with cooked rice, especially fried rice ; nausea and vomiting within 1-6 hours. Some cases may include diarrhoea Other Infections Opportunistic infections: Ocular infections, meningitis, septicemia, endocarditis, osteomyelitis More common in immunocompromised individuals, intravenous drug users, neonates, and post-surgical patients Diagnosis of Bacillus cereus: Diagnostic Method Details Food Poisoning Culture of implicated food essential. >10 5 B. cereus cells per gram confirms the diagnosis. Quantitative stool cultures with at least 10 5 cells per gram support diagnosis. Culture Characteristics Aerobic growth at 37°C on sheep blood agar. β -hemolytic colonies with frosted glass appearance. Motile, lecithinase positive, fermenting salicin Selective Media MYPA aids in isolating B. cereus from faeces and other sources Microscopy Spore-forming, Gram-positive bacilli. Motile Clostridium botulinum (Option B) causes botulism, presenting with descending paralysis and no vomiting, with symptoms appearing 12–36 hours after ingestion. Escherichia coli (Option C) : ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli) causes watery diarrhea, not isolated vomiting, and has a longer incubation period (12–72 hours). Shigella dysenteriae (Option D) : Causes bloody diarrhea (dysentery) with fever, not acute vomiting. Reference: Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 363, 364 Ananthanarayan and Paniker’s Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page 253, 254

questions.question: A farmer presents with fever and subconjunctival hemorrhage. The microscopic agglutination test turns to be positive. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Leptospira Explanation: A farmer with fever and subconjunctival hemorrhage along with a positive microscopic agglutination test points toward Leptospira infection (Leptospirosis). Leptospirosis: Causative Agent Leptospira interrogans (bacteria) Transmission Zoonotic disease Indirect: Contact with water, moist soil, or surfaces contaminated with animal urine. Direct: Contact with urine or parturition products from infected animals. Pathogenesis Phases Septicemic Phase: Entry through mucosa or skin, dissemination via bloodstream to organs. Immune Phase: Antibodies develop, spirochetes disappear from blood; antigen-antibody complexes form, and renal colonization occurs. Clinical Syndromes Mild Anicteric Illness: Seen in 90% of cases, flu-like symptoms with fever , headache, conjunctival suffusion , nausea, vomiting, and myalgia. Weil’s Disease: Severe icteric illness in 10% of cases; rapid progression, fatality rate of 5-15%. Culture Media Ellinghausen-McCullough-Johnson-Harris (EMJH) medium is commonly used for culturing Leptospira species showing Dinger’s ring. IIIIIII It is a semi-solid or liquid medium that supports the slow-growing leptospires, often requiring incubation for weeks. Specimen Sources: Blood, urine, or cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) samples are often used, depending on the stage of infection. Other culture media are Korthoff and Fletcher. Diagnosis Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) : Considered the gold standard for Leptospira detection , MAT measures antibodies in serum samples. The Modified Faine’s Criteria used to aid in the diagnosis of leptospirosis, especially in endemic areas.This scoring system combines clinical, epidemiological and laboratory data to increase diagnostic accuracy. PCR (Polymerase Chain Reaction): Provides a faster diagnosis by detecting leptospira DNA in blood or urine, especially effective in the early stage. ELISA : Used for antibody detection and is helpful for confirming infection in the later stages. Treatment Antibiotics : Early antibiotic therapy is crucial and often involves: Doxycycline : Typically used for mild cases and prophylaxis. Penicillin or Ampicillin: Preferred for severe cases. Brucella (Option A) causes undulant fever and hepatosplenomegaly but does not cause subconjunctival hemorrhage. The standard test is the serum agglutination test (SAT), not the microscopic agglutination test (MAT). Escherichia coli (Option C) primarily causes gastrointestinal and urinary tract infections and is not associated with conjunctival hemorrhage, or a positive MAT. Staphylococcus aureus (Option D) causes skin infections, pneumonia, and endocarditis but does not cause subconjunctival hemorrhage or a positive MAT, which is specific for Leptospira.

questions.question: A 70-year-old man was admitted with a murmur and blood culture positive for Gram-positive cocci. Choose the common agent causing prosthetic valve infective endocarditis.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Staphylococcus epidermidis Explanation: Staphylococcus epidermidis , a coagulase-negative Staphylococcus (CoNS), is the most common cause of prosthetic valve infective endocarditis. Prosthetic Valve Endocarditis: It occurs following cardiac valve replacement. Early prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurs within 12 months of valve replacement): Generally nosocomial. Results from intra-operative contamination of the prosthesis or a bacteremic postoperative complication. Common agents: CoNS (e.g., S. epidermidis ) and S. aureus. Late prosthetic valve endocarditis (occurs after 12 months of valve replacement): Usually community-acquired. Common agents: Viridans streptococci. Overall : Regardless of the time of onset after surgery, CoNS are the most common agents (at least 68-85%). Majority are methicillin-resistant CoNS. Streptococcus viridans (Option A) is a common cause of native valve endocarditis, particularly following dental procedures or in patients with pre-existing valvular disease. However, it is not the primary cause of prosthetic valve endocarditis (PVE), where Staphylococcal species predominate. Staphylococcus aureus (Option C) is a virulent pathogen that causes rapidly progressive (acute) infective endocarditis, affecting both native and prosthetic valves. It is a leading cause of healthcare-associated IE, often seen in intravenous drug users (IVDU) and patients with catheters or implanted devices. While it can cause prosthetic valve IE, it is more common in late-onset cases rather than early PVE. Enterococci (Option D) (e.g., Enterococcus faecalis ) are opportunistic pathogens that cause subacute endocarditis, particularly in elderly patients with genitourinary or gastrointestinal infections. Though they can infect prosthetic valves, they are not the primary causative agent. Reference: Apurba S Sastry’s Essentials of Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 290

questions.question: A patient presents with fever, neck rigidity, headache, vomiting, and petechial rashes on the lower limbs. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Neisseria meningitidis Explanation: The patient's clinical features of fever, neck rigidity, headache, vomiting, and petechial rashes on the lower limbs point toward meningococcal meningitis caused by Neisseria meningitidis. ClinicalFeatures of Neisseria meningitidis: Rashes: Non-blanching rash ( petechial or purpuric) develops in more than 80% of cases. Septicemia: Attributed to endotoxin-induced endothelial injury. Leads to increased vascular permeability and intravascular thrombosis. Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome: Severe form of fulminant meningococcemia. Characterized by large purpuric rashes (purpura fulminans), shock, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), bilateral adrenal hemorrhage, and multiorgan failure. Pyogenic meningitis: Commonly affects young children (3-5 years of age). Presentation includes fever, vomiting, headache, and neck stiffness. Similar to other bacterial meningitis but with the presence of rashes. Chronic meningococcemia: Rare condition. Characterized by repeated episodes of petechial rashes, fever, arthritis, and splenomegaly. Postmeningococcal reactive disease: Develops 4-10 days later due to immune complexes (capsular antigens and their antibodies). Manifestations include arthritis, rash, iritis, pericarditis, polyserositis, and fever. Lab Investigations of Neisseria meningitidis: Investigation Findings Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) Analysis Appearance Cloudy or purulent White Blood Cell Count (WBC) Elevated (pleocytosis), typically >1,000 cells/µL, with predominance of neutrophils Protein Elevated Glucose Decreased Gram Stain Presence of gram-negative diplococci Culture Growth of Neisseria meningitidis on chocolate agar or Thayer-Martin agar Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) Detection of Neisseria meningitidis DNA Latex Agglutination Test Positive for Neisseria meningitidis antigens Blood Tests Culture Growth of Neisseria meningitidis White Blood Cell Count Elevated leukocytosis with left shift Clostridium perfringens (Option B) causes gas gangrene and food poisoning, not meningitis with petechial rash. Cryptococcus neoformans (Option C) is typically seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., HIV) and presents with chronic meningitis without petechial rash. Clostridium difficile (Option D) causes antibiotic-associated diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis, not meningitis Reference: Apurba Sastry's Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 2nd Edition, Page 693,694,697

questions.question: A patient’s laboratory results were positive for malarial antigen, and the Widal test findings were as follows: O ag >1:300, H ag >1:20, A >1:20, B >1:20. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Recent infection by Salmonella spp Explanation: A significantly elevated O antigen titer (>1:300) only in the Widal test suggests a recent Salmonella infection. Widal Test: It is a highly sensitive but poorly specific serological test used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella typhi. It detects specific antibodies in the patient's serum that react with the antigens of Salmonella typhi. The test is based on the agglutination reaction where patient serum is mixed with antigens of Salmonella typhi. If the antibodies are present, they will cause the antigens to clump together (agglutinate), indicating a positive result. The test primarily measures: O-antibodies: These are antibodies against the somatic (O) antigens of Salmonella typhi. H-antibodies: These are antibodies against the flagellar (H) antigens of Salmonella typhi. Antigens Used : O antigen of S. Typhi (TO) H antigen of S. Typhi (TH) H antigen of S. Paratyphi A (AH) H antigen of S. Paratyphi B (BH) Interpretation : Cut-off values in most parts of India : H agglutinin titer >200. O agglutinin titer >100. Low titers : Considered baseline in endemic areas and should be ignored. Widal Test Result Suggestive of Rise of TO and TH antibody Enteric fever due to S. Typhi Rise of TO and AH antibody Enteric fever due to S. Paratyphi A Rise of TO and BH antibody Enteric fever due to S. Paratyphi B Rise of only TO antibody Recent infection due to S. Typhi or S. Paratyphi A or B Rise of only TH antibody Convalescent stage / Anamnestic response Rise of all TH, AH, BH Post-TAB vaccination antibodies (Option B) Past infection (Option C) : A past infection usually results in elevated H antigen titers, whereas in this case, the O antigen titer is significantly high, indicating a recent infection. Reconvalescence (Option D) : In the recovery phase, both O and H antigen titers decline, whereas in this case, the O antigen titer remains markedly high, supporting a recent infection instead. Reference: Apurba S Sastry- Essentials Of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 305-307

questions.question: MOA of botulinum toxin is
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Inhibits the release of acetylcholine Explanation: The mechanism of action of botulinum toxin is inhibition of acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction . Mechanism of Action of Botulinum Toxin: Botulinum toxin binds to acetylcholine receptors at neuromuscular junctions, preventing the release of acetylcholine , which is essential for muscle contraction. This leads to flaccid paralysis, a hallmark of botulism. Inhibits Elongation Factor 2 (Option A): This describes the MOA of Diphtheria toxin and Pseudomonas exotoxin A, which inhibit protein synthesis by ADP-ribosylation of Elongation Factor-2 (EF-2), leading to cell death. Inhibits the release of GABA (Option B): This describes the action of Tetanus toxin, which blocks inhibitory neurotransmitters (GABA and glycine) in the spinal cord, causing spastic paralysis. Increases cAMP (Option D): Toxins that increase cyclic AMP (cAMP) include cholera toxin and pertussis toxin, which cause fluid secretion (diarrhea) and immune modulation, respectively. Reference: Mahon Lehman Textbook of Diagnostic Microbiology, 6th Edition, Page 732 Apurba Sastry Essentials of Medical Microbiology, 3rd Edition, Page 397

questions.question: A person with the H/o long-term sexual relationship presented with painful ulcers on his genitals with tender lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Chancroid Explanation: The clinical scenario of a person with a history of a long-term sexual relationship presenting with painful ulcers on the genitals and tender lymphadenopathy points towards a diagnosis of Chancroid , typically caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. Haemophilus ducreyi: Gram-negative coccobacillus Fastidious, requiring X factor but not V factor Forms characteristic "school of fish" or "railroad track" arrangements in Gram stains Safety pin appearance of bipolar staining. Clinical features of chancroid: Painful genital ulcers with ragged edges and a purulent base Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy (buboes) Incubation period of 3-10 days Diagnosis: Clinical presentation Gram stain of ulcer exudate Culture on selective media (challenging and low sensitivity) PCR (most sensitive method) Differential diagnosis includes syphilis, herpes simplex, and lymphogranuloma venereum Treatment: Azithromycin 1g orally single dose, OR Ceftriaxone 250mg IM single dose, OR Ciprofloxacin 500mg orally twice daily for 3 days, OR Erythromycin 500mg orally three times daily for 7 days Treatment of sexual partners is crucial Gonorrhea (Option A) typically causes urethritis and discharge, not painful ulcers or lymphadenopathy. Chlamydia (Option B) can cause urethritis or cervicitis, but ulcers are rare. Lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) (Option C) presents with painless ulcers and later, painful lymphadenopathy, unlike the painful ulcers seen in chancroid.

questions.question: A patient admitted with fever and nuchal rigidity. CSF analysis shows decreased glucose and increased protein and neutrophils. Choose the correct treatment
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ceftriaxone Explanation: The clinical scenario of a patient with fever, nuchal rigidity, and CSF findings of decreased glucose, increased protein, and neutrophilic pleocytosis points towards a diagnosis of bacterial meningitis. Ceftriaxone is the first-line antibiotic for treatment of bacterial meningitis. Bacterial Meningitis in Adults and Prevention Causes Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes. Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems. Pathophysiological Process Classic Triad of Symptoms Fever Headache Nuchal rigidity (stiff neck) CSF Findings Opening pressure: Elevated Predominant cell type: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils (PMNs) Protein: Elevated Glucose: Decreased Gross appearance: Turbid Treatment Immediate Management: Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens. First-line antibiotic of choice: Ceftriaxone Treatment is then adjusted based on the identified organism and its susceptibility Adjunctive Therapy: Dexamethasone may be given to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly if administered early. Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures. Prevention Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections. Chemoprophylaxis : Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections. Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose Azithromycin 500 mg single dose Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose Ampicillin (Option A) is primarily used in Listeria monocytogenes meningitis, which is more common in neonates, elderly, and immunocompromised patients. It is not first-line for typical bacterial meningitis in healthy adults. Penicillin (Option C) was historically used for Neisseria meningitidis but is not sufficient as monotherapy due to increasing resistance. Empirical therapy requires broader coverage. Vancomycin (Option D) is used in combination with Ceftriaxone when penicillin-resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae is suspected, but it is not sufficient alone.

questions.question: KAT G mutation associated with:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Isoniazid Explanation: The katG mutation causes Isoniazid resistance by preventing its activation inside Mycobacterium tuberculosis, making the drug ineffective. Mechanisms of Isoniazid Resistance KatG gene mutation INH is a prodrug, converted to the active form by catalase-peroxidase produced by the Kat G gene. The mutated catalase enzyme does not form the active drug KasA gene mutation Component of cell wall mycolic acid InhA gene overexpression Causes cross-resistance to Ethionamide (second-line drug) Rifampicin (Option B) resistance is associated with mutations in the rpoB gene (RNA polymerase β -subunit), not KAT G. Levofloxacin (Option C) resistance is linked to mutations in the gyrA and gyrB genes, which encode DNA gyrase, a key enzyme for bacterial DNA replication. Ethambutol (Option D) resistance is associated with mutations in the embB gene, which affects arabinosyl transferase, an enzyme involved in mycobacterial cell wall synthesis. Reference: KD Tripathi Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th Edition, Page 816-818

questions.question: A 10-year-old child presents to the pediatric clinic with complaints of joint pain, swelling, and difficulty in walking. On examination, the child is found to have a tender, swollen knee joint and a history of recent sore throat. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers. A renal biopsy is performed, and it shows glomerular changes consistent with PSGN. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for both the acute rheumatic fever and PSGN in this patient?
questions.explanation: Streptococcus, is the correct answer. This bacterium is responsible for both acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). ARF is a systemic immune-mediated inflammatory disorder that can develop after an untreated or inadequately treated streptococcal pharyngitis (sore throat). It can lead to joint pain, inflammation, and other clinical manifestations. PSGN, on the other hand, is a kidney disease that can occur as a result of an immune response to a streptococcal infection, particularly in the skin or throat. The elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers and the glomerular changes seen on renal biopsy in the given scenario are indicative of a streptococcal infection-related condition. Incorrect Options: Option A - Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of bacterial pneumonia and other respiratory infections. It is not typically associated with acute rheumatic fever or post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). Option C - Streptococcus agalactiae: Streptococcus agalactiae, also known as group B Streptococcus, is a common cause of neonatal infections and can also cause infections in adults with underlying medical conditions. It is not associated with acute rheumatic fever or PSGN. Option D - Streptococcus mutans: Streptococcus mutans is primarily associated with dental caries and oral infections. questions.question: A 28 year old patient presented with watery diarrhoea and dysentery. After taking history, it is noted that he had eaten Oysters on his recent trip. Which of the following can be responsible for his symptoms?

questions.question: A patient presents with abdominal pain, diarrhea, and a step-ladder pattern fever. He also complains of a headache and malaise . His symptoms gradually worsened over the past 2 weeks. Which of the following is the best diagnostic test?

questions.question: A 48 years old man , hospitalized for 17 days and on IV antibiotics followed by oral course of drugs for acute febrile illness with neutropenia. He had a history of dysuria while admitted and now complaints of loose stools and abdominal pain. Which antibiotic usage has the highest risk for developing pseudomembranous colitis ?
questions.explanation: difficile-associated colitis, is a severe inflammatory condition of the colon that can occur as a result of antibiotic usage. Certain antibiotics are known to disrupt the normal gut flora and create an environment favourable for the overgrowth of Clostridium difficile bacteria, leading to the development of pseudomembranous colitis. Among the options provided, aminopenicillin antibiotics have the highest risk for causing pseudomembranous colitis. Aminopenicillins, such as ampicillin and amoxicillin, are broad-spectrum antibiotics commonly used to treat various bacterial infections. However, they can also disrupt the balance of the gut microbiota and increase the risk of Clostridium difficile infection. Incorrect Options: Option A - Carbapenems: Carbapenems are a class of broad-spectrum antibiotics with a lower risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis compared to aminopenicillins. Although they can still disrupt the gut microbiota, their use is not typically associated with a significantly high risk of Clostridium difficile infection. Option C - Macrolides: Macrolide antibiotics, such as erythromycin and azithromycin, are known to have a lower risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis compared to aminopenicillins. While they can still alter the gut microbiota, they are not considered as high-risk antibiotics for Clostridium difficile infection. Option D - Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolone antibiotics, including ciprofloxacin and levofloxacin, have a moderate risk of causing pseudomembranous colitis. While their use can disrupt the gut microbiota and increase the risk of Clostridium difficile infection, the risk is lower compared to aminopenicillins. Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: What is the most probable cause in a case of granuloma with acid-fast bacilli positivity?
questions.explanation: (AFB), leprosy is the most likely cause. Leprosy, also known as Hansen's disease, is a chronic infectious disease caused by the bacteria Mycobacterium leprae. It primarily affects the skin, peripheral nerves, mucosa of the upper respiratory tract, and the eyes. Leprosy is characterized by the formation of granulomas in the affected tissues, which are clusters of immune cells, including macrophages, that surround and attempt to contain the mycobacteria. Acid-fast staining is a diagnostic test used to visualize mycobacteria, such as Mycobacterium leprae, which retain the stain despite being exposed to acid. Option D - Syphilis: Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. questions.question: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival injection, and hematuria for 15 days . Which serological test should be done for diagnosis?

questions.question: HUS in children is caused by:

These toxins can cause damage to the lining of blood vessels, leading to red blood cell destruction, platelet clumping, and kidney injury, which are characteristic features of HUS. questions.question: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below ?
questions.explanation: and has a specific mechanism of action Mechanism of action: Binding: Botulinum toxin binds to presynaptic nerve terminals at the neuromuscular junction. Internalization: The toxin is internalized into the nerve terminal via receptor-mediated endocytosis. Cleavage: Inside the nerve terminal, the toxin undergoes enzymatic cleavage, resulting in the formation of two subunits: a light chain (LC) and a heavy chain (HC). Neurotransmitter release inhibition: The light chain (LC) of the botulinum toxin is a protease that specifically cleaves SNARE proteins involved in neurotransmitter release. SNARE proteins play a crucial role in the fusion of synaptic vesicles containing acetylcholine with the neuronal membrane, allowing the release of acetylcholine into the synaptic cleft. By cleaving SNARE proteins, botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine, leading to muscle paralysis. Temporary effects: The effects of botulinum toxin are reversible, as new SNARE proteins can be synthesized by the affected neuron over time. The duration of paralysis depends on the type of botulinum toxin used and the individual's metabolism. Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an Reference: Prepladder Notes

questions.question: A patient from Uttarakhand presented in the month of September with fever and myalgia after a bite with a mite . The patient was started on IV ceftriaxone, but it did not help; later, the patient noticed cutaneous lesions on examination (black eschar), as given below in the figure. What is your diagnosis ?
questions.explanation: (black eschar) after a bite with a mite in Uttarakhand during September is suggestive of Scrub typhus. Scrub typhus is a bacterial infection caused by the Orientia tsutsugamushi bacterium. It is transmitted to humans through the bite of infected chiggers (larva of trombiculid mites) found in areas with dense vegetation. Scrub typhus is commonly seen in rural areas, particularly in regions with heavy vegetation, such as forests or grasslands. The clinical presentation of scrub typhus includes fever, headache, myalgia (muscle pain), and a characteristic eschar at the site of the chigger bite. The eschar is a black, necrotic lesion surrounded by an area of inflammation. Incorrect Options: Option B - Murine Typhus: Murine typhus is caused by the bacteria Rickettsia typhi, transmitted to humans by rubbing or inhalation of the feces of infected fleas. It typically presents with fever, headache, myalgia, anorexia, and rash (involving the trunk more often than the extremities). Option C - Q Fever: Q fever is caused by the bacteria Coxiella burnetii, transmitted to humans through ingestion of contaminated milk or by handling wools, hides or meat. It can cause a flu-like illness, hepatitis, meningoencephalitis or endocarditis. Option D - Louse Borne Typhus: Louse-borne typhus also known as epidemic typhus, is caused by the bacteria Rickettsia prowazekii and is transmitted to humans through rubbing of louse (Pediculus humanus corporis) feces on an abraded skin. It presents with high fever, headache, and rash starting from trunk and spreading to limbs. Reference: Prepladder Notes
